body: Thanks for the report! Can you describe your system setup? Is there anything out of the ordinary you can think of that may cause this? Common offenders can be things like antivirus or proxies on other platforms
I'm just using a standard macbook pro. The only thing that I can think of is that I'm in China at the moment but I don't know how it would impact the CA

@zcaudate do you perhaps have some Homebrew software that could be interfering? Do command line tools like `curl` work for you? Are you sure, for example, that there's no firewall in the middle switching certificates?
@zcaudate if you execute things like `curl https://crates.io` and `curl https://static.crates.io`, do you get SSL errors?
yep. it's not working with curl.
Ok thanks! That at least means it's not cargo specific. Unfortunately though I don't know how to fix it still, but it's likely a system or network configuration issue than a cargo issue

@zcaudate You can get more details by using `openssl s_client` to connect, e.g. I see a cert signed by Amazon, in turn signed by Starfield Technologies when connecting:

```text
> openssl s_client -connect static.crates.io:443 -servername static.crates.io
CONNECTED(00000006)
depth=3 C = US, ST = Arizona, L = Scottsdale, O = "Starfield Technologies, Inc.", CN = Starfield Services Root Certificate Authority - G2
verify error:num=20:unable to get local issuer certificate
verify return:0
---
Certificate chain
 0 s:/CN=static.crates.io
   i:/C=US/O=Amazon/OU=Server CA 1B/CN=Amazon
 1 s:/C=US/O=Amazon/OU=Server CA 1B/CN=Amazon
   i:/C=US/O=Amazon/CN=Amazon Root CA 1
 2 s:/C=US/O=Amazon/CN=Amazon Root CA 1
   i:/C=US/ST=Arizona/L=Scottsdale/O=Starfield Technologies, Inc./CN=Starfield Services Root Certificate Authority - G2
 3 s:/C=US/ST=Arizona/L=Scottsdale/O=Starfield Technologies, Inc./CN=Starfield Services Root Certificate Authority - G2
   i:/C=US/O=Starfield Technologies, Inc./OU=Starfield Class 2 Certification Authority
```

If you get the same thing then this is likely related to Cargo somehow not having the the "Amazon Root CA 1" certificate in its CA path for some reason. If you get something different then it's more likely to be something on your network attempting to MITM the TLS connection.

Probably! I unfortunately don't know what it would be though :(
